title-group.article-title: A hierarchical constrained density regression model for predicting cluster-level dose-response

article-meta.aff: 1Division of Biostatistics, College of Public Health, The Ohio State University, Columbus, Ohio, USA
2Biostatistics and Computational Biology Branch, Division of Intramural Research, NIEHS, Research Triangle Park, North Carolina, USA
3Predictive Toxicology Branch, Division of Translational Toxicology, NIEHS, Research Triangle Park, North Carolina, USA

author-notes.corresp: Correspondence: Michael L. Pennell, Division of Biostatistics, College of Public Health, The Ohio State University, 246 Cunz Hall, 1841 Neil Avenue, Columbus, OH 43210, USA. pennell.28@osu.edu

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivs License, which permits use and distribution in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited, the use is non-commercial and no modifications or adaptations are made.

abstract.p: With the advent of new alternative methods for rapid toxicity screening of chemicals comes the need for new statistical methodologies which appropriately synthesize the large amount of data collected. For example, transcriptomic assays can be used to assess the impact of a chemical on thousands of genes, but current approaches to analyzing the data treat each gene separately and do not allow sharing of information among genes within pathways. Furthermore, the methods employed are fully parametric and do not account for changes in distribution shape that may occur at high exposure levels. To address the limitations of these methods, we propose Constrained Logistic Density Regression (COLDER) to model expression data from different genes simultaneously. Under COLDER, the dose-response function for each gene is assigned a prior via a discrete logistic stick-breaking process (LSBP) whose weights depend on gene-level characteristics (e.g., pathway membership) and atoms consist of different dose-response functions subject to a shape constraint that ensures biological plausibility. The posterior distribution for the benchmark dose among genes within the same pathways can be estimated directly from the model, which is another advantage over current methods. The ability of COLDER to predict gene-level dose-response is evaluated in a simulation study and the method is illustrated with data from a National Toxicology Program study of Aflatoxin B1.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: In 2008, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, National Toxicology Program (NTP), the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences (NIEHS), National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences, and Food and Drug Administration formed the Tox21 Consortium, a United States federal research collaboration whose goal is to establish new alternative methods (NAM) for rapidly screening chemicals for safety (Krewski et al., 2020; NRC, 2007). Since then, the toxicology community has focused on developing novel high throughput bioassays to investigate chemical toxicity at the molecular level. Given the rapid pace of these advancements, statistical methodologies have lagged the toxicological developments, and in most cases, modelers employ simple and often inefficient model fitting procedures.

An example arises in transcriptomic dose-response studies (e.g., see Ramaiahgari et al., 2019). These are in vitro experiments which examine the effect of chemical exposure on the expression of thousands of RNA transcripts. Currently, the dose-response is modeled separately for each gene to estimate a gene-specific benchmark dose (BMD), the dose causing a biologically pre-specified adverse effect (Crump, 1984). Genes are then grouped according to gene pathway and the median BMD lower bound (BMDL) within the group is used as a pathway-specific point of departure (POD). A POD is a dose that serves as a starting point for extrapolation to safe exposure levels for human populations (U.S. EPA, 2012). The overall chemical-specific POD is typically based upon the most sensitive pathway (National Toxicology Program, 2018).

Though simple to implement, these analyses have some limitations. First, by modeling each transcript separately, such analyses ignore the likely correlation in dose-response among genes in a pathway or among pathways that have some genes in common. Without a model that addresses such correlations, there is no formal mechanism for synthesizing the information. A second limitation is that the models make strict parametric assumptions about the dose-specific distributions of gene expression (typically normality or log-normality), so they do not accommodate possible changes in distribution shape with dose (e.g., see Hwang & Pennell, 2014). Similar issues exist with other NAMs, such as bioassay data produced by the Tox21 research collaboration (Attene-Ramos et al., 2013).

Another limitation of these methods is that they provide no mechanism for prediction. For instance, a common goal in transcriptomic studies is to predict a pathway-level response based on chemically induced changes in expression of individual genes. Similarly, a goal for NAMs that screen thousands of chemicals simultaneously is to predict a chemical’s toxicity based on its structural features and physical chemistry. We formulate both scenarios as cluster-level prediction problems by fitting the data to a hierarchical model structure that is designed to enable such predictions at the highest level of the hierarchy (e.g., gene or chemical in our two examples).

To address the limitations of approaches currently used to analyze data derived from high dimensional NAMs (e.g., transcriptomics), we propose a new Bayesian nonparametric approach to predicting cluster-level toxicity. In our approach, sub-unit level outcomes are modeled using a logistic stick-breaking process (LSBP). Here, the means of each mixture component are modeled using a nonparametric function of dose subject to an umbrella ordering constraint to ensure biological plausibility, and the weights assigned to each element are dependent on cluster-level covariates. The resulting model allows the location, shape, and spread of the response distribution to change with dose and covariate levels, and thus makes fewer assumptions than standard parametric dose-response models. Our method also generates cluster-level predictions of the dose-response that we then use to estimate a posterior distribution of the BMD.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows: In Section 2, we introduce the basic study design and data structure of toxicogenomic studies and high throughput NAMs used to screen thousands of chemicals. Then, in Section 3, we describe our nonparametric model and approach to predicting cluster-level toxicity. In Section 4, we summarize our computational methods and explain how to estimate BMDs. In Section 5 we evaluate the predictive accuracy of our model in a simulation study and compare it to a simpler parametric approach. In Section 6 we apply our methods to a toxicogenomic study of Aflatoxin B1. Finally, in Section 7, we summarize our results and discuss possible extensions of our methods and applications to epidemiological data.

sec.title: Toxicogenomic studies
sec.p: The goal of toxicogenomic studies is to identify biological pathways affected by chemical exposure through dose-response modeling of transcript expression in vitro. To achieve this goal, human or animal cells are seeded onto a collagen(I)-coated 384 well plate and exposed to either a vehicle control (typically 12 replicate wells) or one of several (usually 10) different, half-log spaced, concentrations of a test chemical. Following a pre-determined exposure period, expression levels of thousands of gene transcripts are obtained using a Next Generation sequencing platform. For more information on the study design used by the National Toxicology Program, see Ramaiahgari et al. (2019).

In toxicogenomic studies, the expression level for each sample of cells is a vector-valued response roughly 2000–3000 transcripts in length. However, since our goal is to predict gene-level dose-response using gene-level characteristics, we impose a hierarchical model to facilitate that goal. We regard gene as the cluster (i.e., the top level of the hierarchy) with dose groups nested within genes and samples of cells nested within dose groups. Our imposed model ignores within sample correlations that are not explained by gene-level covariates, which in our motivating example consist of binary variables that identify membership in different gene pathways. However, ignoring these correlations should have minimal impact on the results due to low between sample variability. For instance, in the Aflatoxin B1 experiment analyzed in Section 6, the between sample variance (0.0041) was 0.03% of the total variance in expression when adjusting for dose.

sec.title: High-throughput toxicity screening
sec.p: Studies that fall under the high throughput-testing umbrella have various designs reflective of the type of bioassay. Typically, for cell-based bioassays like Tox21, assays are either a receptor-based reporter or a cell stress reporter-based, with 16 concentrations. Here, there is no “zero-dose” as all doses are chosen as a geometric titration of 100 μM. For each assay, thousands of unique chemicals are tested. One could apply our approach to these data by treating each chemical as a cluster. The model would then predict the response based on structural characteristics of the chemicals.

sec.title: PROPOSED MODEL
sec.p: We now describe our novel Bayesian nonparametric approach to analyzing the NAM data. We begin this section by describing the approach used to model dose-dependent changes in the shape of the response distribution subject to order restrictions on the location. Then, in Section 3.2, we generalize the model to include cluster-level predictors. We conclude this section by defining the BMD in terms of our model and a brief discussion of how our method can be modified to accommodate discrete outcomes.

sec.title: Modeling dose-dependent changes in the response distribution
Density regression model
sec.p: Let yijk denote the response value within cluster i for the kth experimental unit assigned the jth dose, dij (i=1,…,Nc; j=1,…,Di; k=1,…,nij). In toxicogenomic studies, each cluster (gene) is exposed to the same dose-levels (in which case Di=D for all i) but this is not necessarily the case for NAMs which measure toxicity of different chemicals. We assume yijk comes from a dose-dependent distribution Fdi. We would like our model for Fdi to capture changes in shape (e.g., modality and skewness), location, and spread (i.e., variance) with increasing dose that frequently occurs in toxicity studies (e.g., Hwang & Pennell, 2014; Pennell & Dunson, 2008). Our modeling approach has been referred to as “density regression” in the Bayesian nonparametric literature.

A common approach to performing density regression is to use a mixture of normal distributions where either the weights assigned to the mixture components or the means of the individual normal distributions depend on dose. For example, Hwang and Pennell (2014, 2018) used the Kernel stick-breaking process of Dunson and Park (2008) to allow the weights to vary continuously across dose levels for multivariate mixed response data. Fronczyk and Kottas (2017) used the linear dependent Dirichlet process of De Iorio et al. (2004) to model dose-dependent changes in the component means.

Though these models are flexible, modifications are necessary to be consistent with the underlying biology of typical dose-response relationships. With some exceptions, a dose-response should be monotone or biphasic. Biphasic responses typically occur because of cell death at high dose levels. Hwang and Pennell (2014, 2018) impose no constraints on the dose-response and may overfit some data sets leading to unrealistic artifactual bumps in the dose-response. Fronczyk and Kottas (2017) constrain the slope parameters in their model to support isotone trends. While this constraint may be sufficient in some settings, many toxicity assays produce dose-response curves that are nonmonotone or exhibit flat regions.

A more general approach is the isotonic density regression model proposed by Wang and Dunson (2011). With Wang and Dunson’s method, each cluster has the same dose-dependent response distribution (Fdi=Fd; i=1,…,Nc) modeled as follows: (1)Fdyijk=∑l=1∞plΦyijk;μldij,1/ξl, where the pl’s are modeled using a stick-breaking process (Sethuraman, 1994), Φ⋅;μ,v denotes the cumulative distribution function (CDF) of a normal distribution with mean μ and variance v, μld is a shape constrained dose-response function, and ξl is the precision. Though the ξl are independent of dose, the marginal variance, Vdyijk=∑l=1∞plμl2dij+1/ξl−∑l=1∞plμldij2, is not. Wang and Dunson constrained μld to be isotonic. In what follows, we modify (1) to impose other types of shape constraints.

Applying Wang and Dunson’s model directly ignores the clustering we impose to meet our inference goals, so we consider a hierarchical modification of (1). This modification defines a mixture over a discrete prior assigned to a set of cluster-specific parameters, θi=γ0i,ψid,ξi. Here, γ0i is the expected background response or intercept; ψid denotes the shape constrained dose-response function for cluster i; and ξi is the precision of yijk conditional on γ0i, ψid, and dij. We define the following hierarchy: (2)yijkθi,dij∼Nγ0i+ψidij,ξi−1,θi∼G,Gθ=∑l=1∞plδθl∗θ,θl∗∼iidGo, where the θl∗’s are realizations of θi and δθl∗θ=1 if θ=θl∗ and 0 otherwise. We assume that the components of θl∗ are independent a priori; that is, G0θ=G00γ0l∗G0ξξl∗G0ψγl where G00γ0l∗=Nγ0l∗;μ0,v0,G0ξξl∗=Gaξl∗;aξ,bξ, and G0ψγl is a prior assigned to the hyperparameters, γl, which define dose-response function ψl∗. As described in Section 3.1.2, we model ψl∗ using I-spline basis functions with a sign change incorporated to allow umbrella-shaped trends. Thus, γl consists of the spline coefficients and the index of the basis function where the sign change occurs. The notation Ga⋅;a,b used above refers to the cumulative distribution function of a Gamma distribution with mean a/b. If the weights, pl, are modeled using Sethuraman’s (1994) stick-breaking process, (2) can be characterized as a shaped constrained version of the Functional Dirichlet Process Mixture (FDPM) model (Dunson et al., 2008; Petrone et al., 2009).

Though (2) consists of a countably infinite number of dose-response functions, the probabilities assigned to each ψl∗ quickly decay to zero when the pl’s are modeled using a stick-breaking process, as seen in Section 3.2. Thus, the number of moderately small to large pl’s is usually much smaller than the number of clusters. This means that clusters with similar data will likely be assigned the same dose-response function in the posterior. The ability to share dose-response information across clusters is an advantage of our approach over analyses which stratify by cluster; that is, the approach currently used to analyze transcriptomic dose-response data sets.
To improve model flexibility, we specified the following hyperpriors: μ0∼Nm0,v00, τ0=v0−1∼Gaaτ,bτ.

We used an Empirical Bayes approach by setting m0 as the mean response value in the data set among the unexposed dij=0 and v00=1. In our simulations and data example, we let aτ=bτ=1 which is diffuse over moderate levels of the variance. We found that this prior also worked well for the parameters in our normal mixture (i.e., the ξl∗’s) when the marginal variance of the outcome (across dose levels and clusters) equals 1.

Before proceeding further, we wish to clarify our use of the term “cluster” relative to our Bayesian nonparametric model. In our method, cluster refers to the top level of hierarchy in the data (i.e., gene in toxicogenomic studies). We refer to the l terms in the summations of Equations (1) and (2) as “mixture components.” This notation differs from some Bayesian nonparametric publications that refer to the mixture components as clusters, since observations with similar characteristicis are grouped together.

sec.title: Imposing shape constraints
sec.p: We want to incorporate knowledge about the biological mechanisms involved in toxicity experiments by constraining the shape of the dose-response, ψl∗d. From a biological perspective, one would expect the adverse effects of exposure to increase with dose. For instance, Wang and Dunson (2011) imposed monotonicity constraints because they anticipated that gestational age at delivery should decrease as prenatal exposure to dichlorodiphenyldichloroethylene (DDE) increases. However, dose-response curves may be nonmonotonic for in vitro studies when cytotoxicity is present. For example, Figure 1 contains expression data for 10 gene transcripts from a toxicogenomic study of Aflatoxin B1 in HepaRG cells, a human liver cell line. Since aflatoxin is a liver carcinogen, one would expect an increasing dose-response in genes related to cell damage and stress, yet several transcripts exhibit “umbrella” shaped dose-response curves: the trend is increasing at low-to-moderate doses and is decreasing at the high doses. The most likely cause of a down-turn is toxicity-induced cell death. Decreasing dose-response curves are also possible if a toxin down-regulates genes that control the cell cycle. Thus, it would be inappropriate to impose a single monotone increasing constraint in a toxicogenomic study.

To impose our desired shape constraints, we consider the following model: (3)ψl∗d=∑t=1T−1It≥Δlγltgtd, where g1,…,gT are monotone increasing spline basis functions with non-negative coefficients γl1,…,γlT and Δl∼DiscreteUniform1,T+1, is the index of the basis function where the curve changes from monotone increasing to monotone decreasing. When Δl=1, the function is monotone decreasing for all d, and when Δl=T+1, it is monotone increasing over the observed dose range. To impose monotonicity, we use quadratic I-splines (Ramsay, 1988) as they are easy to implement and flexible with a modest number of basis functions.

The shape of ψl∗d is sensitive to the number of basis functions and location of their knots. To ensure that our model is sufficiently flexible, we use several equally spaced knots. For example, we found that in experiments using log-spaced doses, four equally spaced knots from 0.2 to 0.8 are sufficient when doses have been log-transformed and standardized to be between 0 and 1. To avoid over-fitting, we adaptively remove unnecessary basis functions by assigning spike-slab shrinkage priors to the coefficients: (4)πγltω,π0=π0δ0γlt+1−π0Expγltω, where π0∼Betaaπ,bπ is the prior probability that a basis function is excluded from the model and ω∼Gaaω,bω. The exponential distribution in (4) penalizes large values of nonzero spline coefficients. We recommend a noninformative Beta(1, 1) prior for π0 and have found that a ω∼Ga1,1 is a reasonable choice when the outcome is scaled to have a marginal variance of one across doses and clusters.

sec.title: Inclusion of cluster-specific predictors
sec.p: Our primary goal is to develop a model capable of predicting dose-response based on cluster-level characteristics. For example, when each cluster is a gene, we would like to predict the gene’s response to a particular toxin based on the pathways it is involved in. When each cluster is a chemical, we would like to predict the toxicity of a chemical based on its physical properties.

For our density regression model, we would like to use a vector of cluster-level predictors, xi to predict Fdi. Accordingly, we generalize the constrained FDPM in (2) so that each set of cluster-specific parameters, θi, is drawn from its own distribution Gi: (5)Giθi=∑l=1∞plxiδθl∗θi, where, as in (2), θl∗∼iidG0. The function plxi is the probability that a cluster with covariate values xi has intercept γ0∗, dose-response function ψl∗d, and precision ξl∗. This model is intuitively appealing in that xi directly predicts the dose-response function; moreover, if we view the model in terms of the marginal distribution of yijk, (6)Fdiyijk=∑l=1∞plxiNyijk;γ0l∗+ψl∗dij,1/ξl∗, we see that it is actually a density regression with respect to both xi and dij. Therefore, like changes in dose, changes in xi can produce changes in shape, location, and spread of the outcome distribution.

To induce changes in the mixture probabilities with xi, we use a Logistic Stick-Breaking Process (LSBP; Ren et al., 2011): (7)plxi=pl∗xi∏m=1l−11−pm∗xi,logitpl∗xi=fxi;βl, where f⋅ is some function of xi conditional on a set of coefficients, βl∼i.i.d.Nmβ,Vβ. Under (7), the probabilities assigned to each mixture component rapidly decrease with l; this feature is appealing because it implies (5) can be reasonably approximated by a finite number of atoms, simplifying computation. We discuss this feature in more detail in Section 4 and Section A of the Supplementary Material. We henceforth refer to our density regression model with LSBP weights as constrained logistic density regression (COLDER).

In toxicogenomic studies, each covariate is a binary pathway indicator (1 if gene is involved in a particular pathway, 0 otherwise). We use a simple model which assumes linearity in the logit: (8)logitpl∗xi=xi′βl.

Each coefficient in (8) is the log-odds ratio of being assigned to the lth mixture component, conditional on not being assigned to one of the earlier components. If x includes continuous predictors, one may want to consider more flexible regression structures as in Rigon and Durante (2021).

sec.title: Benchmark dose definition
sec.p: The primary purpose of modeling toxicity data is to estimate a dose associated with a minimal level of risk; that is, a BMD (Crump, 1984; U.S. EPA, 2012). Historically, the BMD is a quantity measured for individual dose-response curves. In toxicogenomic studies, a BMD is estimated for each biological pathway of interest by amalgamating estimates for individual genes (e.g., see Ramaiahgari et al., 2019).

A BMD is defined by fixing a level for a benchmark response (BMR). For instance, one could use the absolute relative difference from control: (9)BMR=Eyd=BMD−Eyd=0Eyd=0, where BMR is the specified value of the absolute relative difference and BMD is the dose that satisfies the equation.

The approach currently used to analyze toxicogenomic data is to model each gene’s dose-response separately and use (9) to calculate gene-specific BMDs. The collection of individual gene BMDs in a given pathway provides a distribution of BMDs that can be used to characterize the pathway. Though simple to implement, the approach does not account for differences in the precision of each point estimate.

Instead of pooling point estimates from different models, our approach (COLDER) fits a single model and then calculates a BMD among genes involved in the same pathways; that is, among genes with the same x variables indicating pathway membership. For this calculation, we replace the left side of (9) with an average across all the possible dose-response functions under our mixture model. Thus, we define the expected absolute relative difference (EARD) in the mean: (10)EARDdx=∑l=1∞plxEyx,θl∗,d−Eyx,θl∗,d=0Eyx,θl∗,d=0=∑l=1∞plxψl∗dγ0l∗.
Then, we set a specified value of BMR and define the BMD as follows: (11)BMDx=infd:EARDdx≥BMR.

The resulting BMD defines the benchmark dose as the expected dose related to a biologically significant response across all genes involved in the same pathways. It implicitly defines the BMD distribution as a part of the model and not as something to be computed after fitting each gene separately.

sec.title: Extensions to other outcomes
sec.p: Although we focus on continuous data, our model could be modified to handle other types of outcomes. For instance, let vijk denote the value of a discrete outcome within cluster i for the kth experimental unit assigned the jth dose and yijk, modeled using our approach described in Sections 3.1 and 3.2, is a latent variable underlying vijk. If vijk is an ordinal variable with H levels 0,1,…,H−1, we could use the following link function (Albert & Chib, 1993): (12)vijk=∑h=1Hh−1×Iah−1<yijk<ah, where a0=−∞; a1=0; aH=∞; and a2,…,aH−1 are assigned noninformative priors under the constraint a2<a3<⋯<aH−1. Nandram and Chen (1996) provide an efficient sampling algorithm under this set-up. Note that it follows from (12) that vijk=Iyijk>0 for binary outcomes. A similar relationship can be used when vijk is a count outcome: (13)vijk=∑h=1∞ah×Iah−1<yijk<ah, where a0=−∞, a1=0, a2=1, a3=2, … ; that is, vijk is modeled as a rounded version of yijk (Canale & Dunson, 2011).

sec.title: Summary of MCMC algorithm
sec.p: Posterior inference proceeds using Gibbs sampling. We use a truncation approximation for our nonparametric prior on the distribution of the cluster-specific parameters: (14)Giθi≈∑l=1Lplxiδθl∗θi.

This construction requires pL∗xi=1 in the LSBP (7) to ensure that the mixture weights sum to one. Let f∞y be the marginal density of y based on an infinite dimensional Gi and fLy be the marginal density based on (14). Using Theorem 1 in Ishwaran and James (2002), Rigon and Durante (2021) showed that when Gi is modeled as a logistic stick-breaking process: (15)f∞y−fLy1≤4∑i=1Nc1−𝒫∗xiL−1, where ⋅1 is the L1-norm and 𝒫∗xi=Epl∗xi. The norm in (15) decreases exponentially with L, which implies L does not need to be large to get an accurate approximation of f∞y.

We use a Polya–Gamma (PG) latent variable approach (Polson et al., 2013) to simplify our sampling procedure for βl, 1≤l≤L. This data augmentation technique allows us to draw each βl from a multivariate normal distribution, conditional on a set of latent PG random variables. Details on our MCMC methodology, including full conditional posterior distributions, are provided in Section A of the Supplementary Material. Matlab code for running our model, including an example application using a simulated data set, is also available in the Supplementary Material.

sec.title: Benchmark dose computation
sec.p: The posterior distribution of a predicted BMD is obtained by finding BMDx (11) at each iteration of the MCMC algorithm. If, at a given iteration, the BMR is not achieved within the range of experimental doses or if it will never be achieved (e.g., if the dose-response is flat), we set the BMD to d∞, an arbitrary dose greater than the largest experimental dose. To avoid sensitivity to the choice of d∞, the posterior median should be reported as a point estimate of the BMD instead of the posterior mean.

sec.title: Data generation
sec.p: We conducted a simulation study to evaluate the ability of our model to predict cluster-level toxicity. We generated data to emulate the study design of our real data application, with outcomes simulated from the following mixture model: yijk∼∑l=14λlxiLNwldijk,sl2, where LNw,s2 denotes a log-normal distribution with Elny=w, Varlny=s2, and wldijk=ηl0+ηl1dijk+ηl2dijk2+ηl3dijk3.

The parameter values we used are provided in Table 1. The first mixture component has no dose-response, the second and third components exhibit monotone increasing trends over [0,1], and there is an umbrella-shaped trend for the fourth component (Figure 2). Also, the maximum of the dose-response curve increases with component number.

The mixture-specific weights, λlxi, depend on cluster-specific predictors, xi, through a proportional odds model. We assigned cluster i to a mixture component through a multinomial random variable Zi generated according to the following regression model: (16)logitPZi≤l=β0lλ−xi′βλl=1,2,3.

The cluster-specific covariate vectors consisted of 12 binary variables, xi=xi1,…,xi12′, where each element records presence or absence of a cluster-level attribute (e.g., involvement in a particular gene pathway). The xi were drawn from a multivariate probit model with means for underlying normal random variables chosen to generate expected values for binary variables ranging from 0.05 (5% prevalence of an attribute) to 0.25 (25% prevalence) and a covariance matrix based on the gene pathway indicators in the toxicogenomic study described in Section 6. The intercepts in (16) are in Table 1 and the coefficient vector was βλ=0,0,0.4,0,0,0,0,0,0,0.8,1.2,0′.
Thus, the 3rd, 10th, and 11th attributes increased the chances that a cluster responded to exposure, while the other nine covariates were not associated with cluster-level toxicity.

The parameter values for the probit model used to simulate xi are reported in Section B of the Supplementary Material. Two different scenarios were considered. In the first scenario, the attributes with nonzero coefficients (x3, x10, and x11) had high prevalence (20%, 25%, and 20%, respectively), which resulted in marginal probabilities of 0.51, 0.21, 0.14, and 0.14 for Zi=1,2,3,4, respectively; that is, a roughly 50–50 split of affected and unaffected clusters. In the second scenario, we decreased the prevalence of x3, x10, and x11 (10%, 15%, and 10%, respectively), which decreased the prevalence of affected clusters by 5% (marginal probabilities of 0.56, 0.20, 0.13, and 0.11 for Zi=1,2,3,4, respectively).

We initially examined moderate sample sizes for each simulation scenario so a large number of data sets could be analyzed in a reasonable amount of time. In these moderate dimensional scenarios, we used seven dose groups (dose = 0, 0.1, 0.3, 0.5, 0.7, 0.9, 1) and chose the number of replicates in each group to emulate the toxicogenomic study in Section 6: 12 replicates in the unexposed group and three replicates in each exposed group, resulting in 30 observations per cluster. Two hundred data sets were generated, each consisting of 200 clusters. At the suggestion of an anonymous reviewer, we subsequently created large sample size versions of Scenarios 1 and 2 (Scenarios 1L and 2L, respectively) to evaluate the performance of our method when the sample size was similar to the data application. In these additional scenarios, we used 11 dose groups (dose = 0, 0.1 to 1 spaced by 0.1) with 12 replicates in the unexposed group and three replicates per exposed dose group (i.e., 42 observations per cluster) and 2000 clusters. However, due the increased computational demand, we only analyzed 20 data sets.

sec.title: Analysis methods
sec.p: We implemented our methodology as described in Sections 3 and 4. We selected four interior knots (0.2, 0.4, 0.6, and 0.8) with the quadratic I-spline basis functions and divided outcome values by 10 before analysis to make the scale compatible with our recommended priors on the spline coefficients. We assigned multivariate normal priors with mean mβ=1,012′ and covariance matrix Vβ=100×I13 to each coefficient in the LSBP β1,…,βL−1. In the smaller sample size scenarios (1 and 2), we truncated the stick-breaking prior for Gi at L=20 and ran our MCMC method for 20,000 iterations following a burn-in of 2000 with every 10th iteration saved to thin the chain. In the larger sample size scenarios (1L and 2L), we increased the truncation level to L=40 and number of burn-in iterations to 22,000. We ran the chains in parallel on two different servers: a Windows 2012 server (Dual Intel Xeon E5–2640 Processors, 8 Cores, 16 threads at 2.6 GHz, and 32 GB of RAM) and a Windows 2022 server (Dual Intel Xeon Platinum 8168 Processors, 8 Cores, 16 threads at 2.7 GHz, and 16 GB of RAM).

We evaluated the ability of our method to estimate the expected dose-response, Eyijkdij,xi, and the BMD corresponding to BMRs of 20% and 100% absolute relative differences from control. These effect levels were chosen to assess the ability to estimate BMDs from different regions of the dose-response curve. Because a 5% lower bound on the BMD is commonly used to determine safe exposure levels in humans, we also examined the coverage probabilities (CP) of 95% lower one-sided credible intervals on the BMD. We estimated BMDs for eighteen different covariate profiles: one profile corresponding to x=012, 12 profiles in which only one of the 12 binary covariates was non-zero, and the remaining 5 consisted of profiles in which 2–3 covariates were nonzero (Supplementary Table B.3). If the BMR was not reached within the experimental dose range, we set the BMD to 1.001.

We compared our method to the NTP’s current approach for estimating PODs from toxicogenomic studies (Ramaiahgari et al., 2019). The data for each cluster were log2 transformed and modeled separately using the following normal random error models available in the software package ToxicR (Wheeler et al., 2022): Hill, power, quadratic polynomial, exponential-3, and exponential-5. The model with the smallest AIC was used to estimate the BMD and BMDL. Unstable estimates (BMD 95% upper bound/BMDL > 40) were set to missing. We then estimated a BMD and BMDL for each covariate profile by calculating the median value of each among clusters with that profile. As with our approach, BMD estimates were set to 1.001 if they exceeded the experimental dose range.

sec.title: Scenario 1
sec.p: In general, for Scenario 1, our method accurately estimated the dose-response with the true curves all lying within the middle 50% of the estimates from 200 data sets (Figure 3 and Supplementary Figure B.1). When a covariate profile included x12=1, the estimates were highly variable and positively biased, an unsurprising result since x12=1 is rare (5% prevalence) and since x12 is moderately correlated with x3 (tetrachoric correlation = 0.486), which is predictive of cluster-level toxicity.

Our method also performed well in terms of BMD point and interval estimation, particularly for covariate profiles in which at least one true predictor (x3, x10, or x11) equals one (Table 2). At the lower BMR, the COLDER point estimates of the BMD exhibited small positive bias (< 10%) and the one-sided credible intervals were conservative. Biases were smaller and credible intervals were less conservative at the larger BMR as expected since these BMDs came from the middle of the dose-response curve. However, a somewhat unexpected result was that when x12=1, the bias of the COLDER BMD estimates was similar to other covariate profiles. Thus, although our estimates of the expected response were biased in these scenarios, the estimated BMD was reasonably accurate (or at least for the BMRs considered). In general, BMDs estimated using the approach currently adopted by the NTP (i.e., using the median estimate per profile or MED-EST approach) exhibited greater positive bias. The results were particularly poor for two profiles: when x3 was the only non-zero covariate and when x3 and x12 were the only non-zero covariates. It is noteworthy that these were also the only profiles in Table 2 in which the MED-EST estimates were based on less than 85% of the data. In both instances, missingness was due either to unstable estimates (around 10% of the data sets in each case) or to individual simulated data sets having no observations with those profiles (roughly 10% of the data sets for x3=1, 63% for x3 and x12=1) (Supplementary Table B.5).

COLDER BMD estimates were slightly more biased for the covariate profiles not listed in Table 2, but they were still superior to the MED-EST estimates (Table B.4). At the lower BMR, a couple of COLDER BMD estimates had biases that were just over 10%. The COLDER credible intervals were also less conservative than the covariate profiles listed in Table 2 but, except for one instance with CP = 0.935, did not fall below the nominal coverage rate. With the exception of one profile (all covariates equal 0), the MED-EST BMDs were considerably biased and several data sets had to be excluded due to numerical problems. The numerical issues were expected due to the higher probability of a flat dose-response for these profiles.

sec.title: Scenario 2
sec.p: COLDER still performed well in terms of dose-response (Supplementary Figures B.2 and B.3) and BMD estimation (Supplementary Tables B.6 and B.7) when we decreased the prevalence of the attributes associated with dose-response. The biggest change was in the estimates for profiles 4 (x3=1) and 16 (x3=x12=1), whose dose-response curves were positively biased. This bias is due in part to the low prevalence of x3 and its high correlation with x10 (tetrachoric correlation = 0.745), which was more common and associated with a steeper dose-response. The BMDs of these profiles were more biased than the Scenario 1 estimates (Table 2), but still reasonably close to the true values. The NTP’s current approach (MED-EST) again performed poorly in this scenario and provided BMD estimates that were consistently more biased than the COLDER estimates (Supplementary Tables B.6 and B.7).

sec.title: Large dimension scenarios
sec.p: When we increased the number of clusters in Scenarios 1 and 2, COLDER produced dose-response curves that were less variable across data sets (Supplementary Figures B.4 to B.7) and more precise interval estimates for the BMD (Supplementary Tables B.9, B.10, B.12, and B.13). Dose-response curves for rare attributes, (x12=1, x3=1 in Scenario 2), were less biased over the higher doses, but the BMD estimates were similar to the smaller sample size scenarios. There was one instance (Scenario 1 L, x11=1, BMR = 1.0) with a coverage probability of 0.9, but with only 20 data sets this means that only two intervals did not contain the true BMD. Except for a few cases, the BMD estimates provided by MED-EST were considerably more biased than the COLDER estimates (Supplementary Tables B.9, B.10, B.12, and B.13).

sec.title: APPLICATION TO TOXICOGENOMIC STUDY OF AFLATOXIN B1
Data description and analysis methods
sec.p: We applied our model to a recent toxicogenomic study of Aflatoxin B1, a mutagen produced by fungi found in decaying grains. HepaRG cells were seeded onto a collagen(I)-coated 384 well plate and exposed to either a vehicle control (12 replicate wells) or one of 10 different, half-log spaced, concentrations of Aflatoxin B1 (3 wells per dose). After 96 hours of exposure, expression levels of 2977 gene transcripts were measured by the TempOSeq S1500+ platform from BioSpyder (Yeakley et al., 2017). Expression levels (in read counts) were divided by the total mapped read counts (across all transcripts) in a well and multiplied by 106 to produce normalized expression levels in counts per million (CPM). Cytotoxic doses were retained. Ramaiahgari et al. (2019) provide more details regarding the experimental design.

Our analytical goal was to build a model that could be used to predict a gene’s response to Aflatoxin B1 exposure based on the pathways it is involved in. Thus, the cluster-level covariates in our model consisted of 49 binary variables each of which indicated a gene’s involvement in the different hallmark pathways identified by Liberzon et al. (2015). To improve fit, we also included all pairwise interactions between these variables.

Before analysis, we preprocessed the data to improve computational efficiency and numerical stability. First, several genes could not be reliably modeled since they had very small variability with most, if not all, wells having read counts equal to zero. Thus, we removed all genes with a variance (across all dose levels) less than 0.15 CPM2 leaving 2894 genes for analysis. We then transformed CPM levels as y=log2CPM+1/σ., where σ. is the standard deviation of the log-transformed CPM values across all genes and wells. The log-transformation is standard practice for transcriptomic data. We divided by σ. to obtain a marginal variance equal to 1, following the recommendation in Section 3.1.2. Doses were standardized to be between [0,1] using the following expression: d=logc+cmin/10−logcmin/10logcmax+cmin/10−logcmin/10, where c is the original dose in nanomoles (nM), cmin=4.7 (the smallest non-zero dose in the study), and cmax=149,972.3 (the largest dose). We included the final data set used in our analysis in the Supplementary Material.

Predictions of the dose-response and BMD were made for 57 different covariate profiles: profile 1 corresponded to a gene not involved in any of the hallmark pathways, profiles 2–50 corresponded to genes involved in only one of the pathways, and profiles 51–57 corresponded to genes involved in exactly two pathways whose indicator variables had a tetrachoric correlation greater than 0.7 (Supplementary Table D.1). To simplify our explanation of the results, we will henceforth refer to these profiles as “pathway profiles.” Since the data were log-transformed, the BMD was based on the expected absolute difference (EAD) from control: (17)EADdx=∑l=1∞plxEyx,θl∗,d−Eyx,θl∗,d=0=∑l=1∞plxψl∗d.
We considered BMRs of log2(1.2) and 1, which correspond to 20% and 100% (two-fold) absolute relative differences in CPM from control.

We implemented our method under a truncation level of L=40 which, according to (15), meant that the L1 norm between the marginal distribution of the truncated and un-truncated models was no larger than 2.6 × 10−9. We ran our MCMC algorithm for 20,000 iterations following a burn-in of 24,000 and saved every 10th iteration to thin the chain. Otherwise, the priors and implementation of the MCMC algorithm were identical to the simulation study. The analysis took 3.7 weeks using the same computing resources as the simulation study. Convergence was acceptable as seen in Figures D.3 to D.8 in the Supplementary Material. The results to follow are from this single chain. However, to further examine convergence, we ran two additional chains with different starting configurations for the cluster-specific parameters (the θi’s). The Gelman–Rubin statistic for each BMD equaled 1 (when rounded to three decimal places), which also supported convergence of our MCMC algorithm.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: For each of the most common profiles consisting of at least one hallmark pathway, our model predicted that expression levels were similar to background until the dose of Aflatoxin B1 exceeded 50% of the maximum dose on our standardized scale (Figure 4). Although our predicted EADs appeared to agree well with the observed mean and median EADs for most profiles, for some profiles, our model failed to capture some moderate increases at the low doses. Nevertheless, our model did an excellent job identifying large changes in expression from background. Similar trends were observed for the other pathway profiles we considered (Supplementary Figure D.1).

The posterior distributions of the predicted BMDs based on 20% (BMD20) and 100% (BMD100) relative increases from control differ considerably among profiles (Figure 5 and Supplementary Figure D.2). Due to some lack of fit in the low dose-range, our BMD20s are likely over-estimates for some profiles, such as Path28 (genes only involved in the MYC Targets V1 pathway). However, the BMD100s should be accurate for most profiles since our model fit the data well within the range of doses associated with that BMR (0.6–1.0 on the standardized scale). With a few exceptions, the current approach of estimating the BMD and BMDL based on the median value across genes with the same pathway profile (MED-EST) provided larger BMD20s than COLDER. There was better agreement in the BMD100s across methods and the differences were not systematic (Figure 5 and Supplementary Figure D.2).

We also implemented our method under L=60 to examine the sensitivity of COLDER to truncation level. We ran more iterations for this analysis (25,000 iterations following a burn-in of 39,000) since convergence was slower. However, all other analytical conditions were the same between L=40 and L=60. The median BMD20s and BMD100s were similar under the two-truncation levels, especially for the more common pathway profiles (Supplementary Figure D.9). In general, increasing the truncation level increased the credible interval widths (Supplementary Figure D.10), which led to less agreement in the BMDLs (Supplementary Figure D.9). Thus, we feel that L=40 is a good choice for this analysis since the point estimates were similar to the larger truncation level, but more precise.

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: Motivated by the need for improved methods for analyzing high dimensional dose-response data, we proposed a Bayesian nonparametric method for predicting cluster-level potency subject to an umbrella ordering constraint on the dose-response. In contrast to simpler parametric models, our approach allows the shape and spread of cluster-specific (e.g., gene-specific) response distributions to change with dose. Also, by modeling clusters simultaneously instead of the standard one-cluster-at-a-time approach, we are able to share information across clusters and estimate BMDs among clusters that share certain characteristics (e.g., genes involved in the same biological pathways).

Our simulation study highlighted several advantages of COLDER relative to NTP’s current method of analyzing toxicogenomic data (MED-EST). COLDER outperformed MED-EST in terms of bias of BMD estimates and coverage rates of the one-sided intervals used to estimate the BMDL. Also, since a regression model is used to predict the dose response function, COLDER can estimate BMDs for any desired combination of covariate values whereas MED-EST requires at least one observation per combination. Finally, when the dose-response for a cluster is flat or exhibits a weak signal, our method avoids the stability problems of MED-EST by shrinking the spline coefficients toward zero.

We used the LSBP to incorporate covariates into our model and perform cluster-level predictions. Alternatives to the LSBP include the Kernel Stick-Breaking Process (KSBP; Dunson & Park, 2008) and Probit Stick-Breaking Process (PSBP; Chung & Dunson, 2009; Rodriguez & Dunson, 2011). Rigon and Durante (2021) found that the three models provided a similar level of flexibility when applied to an environmental epidemiology study. There is some difference in computational complexity since the KSBP requires Metropolis–Hastings sampling while coefficients in the LSBP and PSBP models can be sampled from normal posteriors conditional on a set of auxiliary variables.

We defined the BMR in terms of an EARD. One limitation of the EARD is that it does not take the outcome’s variability into account, which Crump (2002) argues could make it difficult to compare the BMDs of some outcomes. Thus, as an alternative, Crump suggests defining the BMR in terms of standard deviation differences from control. This approach is also possible using our method and it would proceed in a similar fashion as Hwang and Pennell (2014), who estimated the BMD using a Bayesian semiparametric joint model for a binary outcome and a continuous response.

Another limitation of our method is the long computation time required for large data sets, such as the toxicogenomic study of Aflatoxin B1. Given that these analyses are used, in part, to establish safe exposure levels of chemicals, the importance of generating accurate potency levels should outweigh the inconvenience of running an analysis for a few weeks. However, we acknowledge that these run times will discourage some from using our approach and thus faster computational alternatives to MCMC are worth pursuing in the future.

Extensions should also be explored to account for additional structure in toxicogenomic experiments. For example, we ignored sources of variation associated with the location of wells on 384-well plates. A relatively simple modification would be to include a normally distributed random effect for well. However, this approach would assume an exchangeable correlation structure across genes, which we believe is unlikely, even after accounting for pathway membership. The analysis we presented in this paper was from a single plate whereas most toxicogenomic experiments are run in triplicate. NTP’s approach to analyzing the data is to analyze each plate separately and report the range of BMDs; this is easy to emulate using COLDER assuming that the different models can be run in parallel. Combining the plates into a single model is appealing because it would provide a single estimated BMD per pathway profile instead of a range. A practical way of doing this would be to average the expression levels of the replicate wells on each plate and run COLDER treating the means from each plate as the replicates. Additional analyses involving real and simulated data are needed to evaluate the benefits of combining plates relative to analyzing them separately.

Modifications are also needed when the primary goal is to group dose-response curves of different clusters. Our LSBP groups clusters, but many of these groups are similar with small separation between the group-specific curves. This behavior is typical of stick-breaking priors (Quinlan et al., 2021). Alternate methods, such as the recently proposed repulsive mixture models (Quinlan et al., 2021), would be worth pursuing in these situations.

Finally, although our methodology was motivated by chemical toxicity data, it could be applied to other biomedical studies with functional response data. For instance, in studies of child development, there may be interest in identifying factors that predict growth curves. One specific example is Chen et al. (2006), who compared the growth of children enrolled in the U.S. Collaborative Perinatal Project according to mother’s smoking status during pregnancy. In this situation, our method could be modified to impose a simple increasing order restriction similar to Wang and Dunson (2011), to reflect the expected trend in height and weight among children and adolescents. The cluster-level covariates could include mother’s smoking status and demographic factors such as household income.

caption.p: Dose response data for 10 gene transcripts from a toxicogenomic study of Aflatoxin B1. We clustered transcripts into 10 groups based on average expression at each dose and plotted two randomly selected genes from each of the five most populous groups. X’s denote observed values; solid lines are shape preserving cubic interpolations (‘pchip’ option in interp1 function in Matlab 2021b).
Unique dose-response functions for mixture components in the data-generating model in the simulation study. Labels give the number of the mixture component.

Expected dose-response for Simulation Scenario 1: covariate profiles in which at least one true predictor (x3, x10, or x11) equals one. For each simulated data set, we estimated the expected dose-response using the posterior mean of Eyijkdij,xi. The median, 25th, and 75th percentiles across 200 data sets are plotted.

Expected absolute difference in expression from control: the most common pathway profiles considered in the Aflatoxin B1 study. N refers to the number of genes with each profile. Dose-specific sample means and medians were computed independently (i.e., no modeling or smoothing) using the expression data from all genes with the same pathway profile. Posterior means and 95% credible intervals (CI) were computed using Constrained Logistic Density Regression (COLDER).
Posterior Distribution of the benchmark dose (BMD): the most common pathway profiles considered in the Aflatoxin B1 study.
Mixture parameters used in the simulation study.
Benchmark dose estimates for simulation Scenario 1: covariate profiles in which at least one true predictor (x3, x10, or x11) equals one (i.e, those shown in Figure 3).

fn.p: Note: CP, proportion of data sets in which 5% BMDL < True value. COLDER, our method. MED-EST, median BMD & BMDL from separate parametric models fit to each cluster. Covariates listed under each “Covariate Profile” equal 1, all other covariates equal 0.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Denotes that values were missing from > 30 (15%) of the data sets due to no observations with the covariate pattern or unstable estimates.
